title: Carolina Youth Symphony performs at Peace Center
text:
Carolina Youth Symphony performs at Peace Center Paul Hyde , phyde@greenvillenews.com 6:47 p.m. EDT October 23, 2015 The Carolina Youth Symphony’s season-opening concert takes place Sunday, with 230 young musicians featured. Three ensembles will be spotlighted. The top orchestra will be joined by 21 members of the Greenville Symphony Orchestra. (Photo: Yon Chong) 11 CONNECT 7 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
As it begins its 60th season, the Carolina Youth Symphony has never been stronger. 
More young musicians than ever — a total of 230 — perform in the three orchestras that operate under the Carolina Youth Symphony banner. 
In addition, the organization’s top ensemble, the Symphony Orchestra, is looking forward to its sixth trip to New York’s famed Carnegie Hall next spring. 
But first, the three orchestras will present their season-opening concert Sunday, 5 p.m. in the Peace Center’s 2000-seat Concert Hall. 
The concert will spotlight young musicians, ages 8 to 18, from 80 schools and 37 cities in the Upstate region. 
Leading the show will be performances by the Repertory and Concert orchestras, generally consisting of younger students. 
The Symphony Orchestra, for its part, will be joined 21 professional musicians from the Greenville Symphony Orchestra for a “Side-by-Side Concert.” 
The student musicians “really pick up their game with those pros playing around them,” said Les Hicken, conductor of the Symphony Orchestra. 
With the 21 Greenville Symphony musicians, the Symphony Orchestra will number about 125 players. 
“They’ll make a joyful noise,” Hicken said. 
The Symphony Orchestra will perform challenging works such as Beethoven’s “Egmont” Overture. 
“Tackling a piece like the Beethoven is a great experience for the students,” said Hicken, who has served as artistic director of the Carolina Youth Symphony for 17 years. “It’s such wonderful music.” 
Also on the Symphony Orchestra’s program is Aaron Copland’s “The Promise of Living” (from the American composer’s only opera “The Tender Land”), Grieg’s “Peer Gynt” Suite and the third movement of Howard Hanson’s Symphony No. 2 (subtitled “Romantic”). 
The Repertory Orchestra, led by Ginger Greer, will offer works by Robert Sheldon, John Whitney and Douglas Wagner. The Concert Orchestra’s program, directed by James Kilgus, includes pieces by Dvorak, Holst, Gabriel Musella and the late Greenville composer Dwight Gustafson. 
The Symphony Orchestra will take portions of Sunday’s program to Carnegie Hall in March. 
For the Carnegie program, the orchestra is also commissioning an original work by Jay Bocook, director of athletic bands at Furman University. In New York City, the orchestra will be featured with other ensembles from around the country. 
A trip to the storied Carnegie Hall never fails to inspire and impress the orchestra’s young musicians, Hicken said. 
“My favorite part of the trip is when the students walk onstage for the dress rehearsal for the first time,” said Hicken, who is also the longtime director of bands and professor of music education at Furman University. “They walk out in awe.” 
While in New York, the Carolina Youth Symphony always finds time to take its young musicians to a Broadway show as well as to Chinatown for shopping and Little Italy for a bite to eat. 
For the latest in local arts news and reviews, follow Paul Hyde on Facebook and Twitter: @PaulHyde7.
